author: @vitoroliveira6170
text: If you want to use the sklearn train_test_split, you can use the following code:  def custom_preprocessing(X, y):     labels = df['class'].unique()     dataset = dict((label, []) for label in labels)          for x_, y_ in zip(X, y):         dataset[y_].append(x_.tolist())          return dataset  X = np.array(df.drop('class', axis=1)) y = np.array(df['class']) X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y) train_dataset = custom_preprocessing(X_train, y_train) test_dataset = custom_preprocessing(X_test, y_test)  correct, total = 0, 0  for group in test_dataset:     for data in test_dataset[group]:         vote = k_nearest_neighbors(train_dataset, data, k=5)                  if group == vote:             correct += 1         total += 1  print('Accuracy:', correct / total)

author: @nairbt1353
text: FOR ANYONE ENCOUNTERING KeyError: 1.0 OR SIMILAR ERRORS The breast cancer dataset was modified so that the label (4 or 2) was the second column instead of the last column.  Change this snippet:   for i in train_data:     train_set[i[-1]].append(i[:-1])  for i in test_data:     test_set[i[-1]].append(i[:-1])  to this:  for i in train_data:     train_set[i[0]].append(i[0:])  for i in test_data:     test_set[i[0]].append(i[0:])  It worked perfectly for me.

author: @ironbarbassey
text: Shouldn't scikit-learn use a balanced accuracy to score the model? I used this on my dataset of roughly 2 unaffected:1affected and was initially quite excited about the result (your tutorial and code were a great help, btw). The data in your example are similarly unbalanced. I used the following code to calculate my own balanced accuracy. It should work if pasted at the end of your sklearn nearest neighbors example. It compares my calculation of accuracy and balanced accuracy to the clf.score (pardon my amateur coding):   predicted_unaffected = np.count_nonzero(predicted == 2) predicted_affected = np.count_nonzero(predicted == 4) actual_unaffected = np.count_nonzero(actual == 2) actual_affected = np.count_nonzero(actual == 4) correct_unaffected = np.count_nonzero(np.logical_and(predicted == 0, actual == 0)) correct_affected = np.count_nonzero(np.logical_and(predicted == 3, actual == 3)) acc = ((correct_unaffected + correct_affected)/(actual_unaffected + actual_affected)) bacc = ((correct_unaffected/actual_unaffected) + (correct_affected/actual_affected))/2  print(predicted_unaffected, predicted_affected, actual_unaffected, actual_affected) print(correct_unaffected,correct_affected) print(acc, bacc) print(accuracy)

author: @superfreestyleer
text: I believe this portion :  test_size = 0.2 train_set = {2:[], 4:[]} test_set = {2:[], 4:[]} train_data = full_data[:-int(test_size*len(full_data))] test_data = full_data[-int(test_size*len(full_data)):]  to be incorrect. Putting the "-" before the int's makes it so that the first 20% is training data and the last 80% is testing data when I believe your intention was to have 80% train and 20% test. I found this by printing train and test after they were assigned and assigning test_size to .99 This makes the train set very small and the test set very big to the point that accuracy is negatively effected. I believe just removing the minus signs makes it correct.
